questions.correct_answer: D. Hyperpolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperpolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release Retinal photoreceptor cells contain a specialized outer segment (OS) compartment that functions in the capture of light and its conversion into electrical signals in a process known as Phototransduction. Shining light on a photoreceptor, either a rod or a cone, leads to membrane hyperpolarization rather than depolarization In the dark , when photoreceptors are relatively depolarized , the number of open Ca2+ channels in the synaptic terminal is high, and the rate of transmitter release is correspondingly great In the light , when receptors are hyperpolarized , the number of open Ca2+ channels is reduced, and the rate of transmitter release is also reduced.

Highyeild:

In Light- Na+ channels close Efflux of K+ continues Hyperpolarization Closure of Ca2+ channels Release of neurotransmitter stops

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .Depolarization, increase in Neurotransmitter release- This is incorrect there is Hyperpolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release Option B .Depolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release-This is incorrect there is Hyperpolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release Option C. Hyperpolarization, increase in Neurotransmitter release-This is incorrect there is Hyperpolarization, decrease in Neurotransmitter release.

Extraedge:

Mutations within most of the phototransduction proteins have been associated with retinal diseases.Mutations in the genes encoding rhodopsin , CNGA1,CNGB1,PDE64 OR PD6B causes retinitis pigmentosa (RP) , where mutations in the gene encoding arestin ,rhodopsin kinase or NCKX1 cause congenital stationary night blindness(CSNB) .

questions.text: Which of the statements is not a feature of Complicated Cataract? (Ophthalmology)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Krukenberg Spindle A complicated cataract refers to the opacification of the crystalline lens secondary to intraocular diseases, mainly intraocular inflammatory conditions that include anterior, intermediate, or posterior uveitis. The cataract typically begins as a posterior subcapsular cortical cataract. The opacity is irregular in outline, appearing as 'BREADCRUMB' in the slit lamp. A characteristic sign is the appearance of iridescent colored particles "polychromatic lustre" of reds, greens, and blues Krukenberg spindle is not a feature of complicated cataracts. The slit lamp examination in pigmentary glaucoma shows a pattern of pigment deposition on the back of the cornea-endothelium called Krukenberg spindles .

Highyeild:

Complicated Cataract is a type of Cataract that results due to nutritional abnormalities in the lens which usually occurs due to degenerative or inflammatory diseases of the eye other than the lens. Some of the conditions causing it include - Chronic Anterior Uveitis/Iridocyclitis (Option C) Ciliary Body Tumours Retinitis Pigmentosa Retinal Detachment Degenerative Myopia Gyrate Atrophy Key Clinical Features of complicated Cataracts are Breadcrumb Appearance(Option A) Polychromatic Lustre (rainbow-like display) (Option B)

Extraedge:

There is a characteristic opacity that begins to set in the Cortex in its posterior part which leads to Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

questions.text: Match the following options correctly? Choose the correct answer from below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-1, b-4, c-2, d-3 Ishihara test is a color vision test for detection of red-green color deficiencies Goldmann Applanation Tonometer is an instrument that is based on Imbert-Fick law. Gold standard instrument for measurement of Intraocular pressure (IOP) Perimetry is the systematic measurement of visual field function (the total area where objects can be seen in the peripheral vision while the eye is focused on a central point) Tangent screen perimetry evaluates the central 30 degrees field at 1 m. The test is done on each eye separately, with the opposite eye patched.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Pterygium?

options.label: B
options.text: It comprises of head neck and body

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simple excision reduces 95% recurrence Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It is a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc. Has 3 parts mainly, a head (apical part on the cornea), a body (the region between the limbus and canthus), and a cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head). (Option B) Patients may complain of itching and grittiness due to Dellen (localized drying effect). Pterygium is of 2 types (Option D) Progressive , which is thick, fleshy, and vascular. Regressive which is thin, atrophic, and attenuated.

Highyeild:

Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence. The recurrence rate of pterygium is around 80% after simple surgical excision. Excision together with adjunctive therapies such as mitomycin C or 5-fluorouracil can reduce the risk of recurrence to approximate 10%

Extraedge:

Patients who present with a history of recent enlargement are more likely to require early excision for subsequent aggressive growth. Aggressive growth or an atypical appearance should prompt an excision biopsy .

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Optic Neuritis :

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: There is no pain on ocular movement

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) is seen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) is seen Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light in the presence of a Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) It is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response observed. Normally, both pupils should have remained constricted in the absence of any defect. In the presence of RAPD, when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye, both pupils dilate. Marcus Gunn pupil is a rare condition that affects the eyes, causing each to respond differently when a light is shone into them. This response indicates that there is dysfunction or disease in the optic nerve or retina. It is a type of relative afferent pupil defect (RAPD)

Highyeild:

Argyll Robertson Pupil AR Pupils are small (miosis), irregular in outline and have light near dissociation. They react poorly to light but very well to near reflex. AR Pupils are usually bilateral and symmetrical. Vision grossly intact. Causes of Optic Neuritis:- Marcus Gunn pupil is seen In optic neuritis. It is also common in retrobulbar optic neuritis due to multiple sclerosis but only for 3-4 weeks. Infection (e.g. syphilis, Lyme disease, herpes zoster), Autoimmune disorders (e.g. lupus, neurosarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica), Inflammatory bowel disease, Drug induced (e.g.chloramphenicol, ethambutol, Isoniazid, streptomycin, quinine, penicillamine, Aminosalicylic acid, phenothiazine, phenylbutazone), Vitamin B12 deficiency Diabetes Mellitus

Extraedge:

CAUSES:- DISEASE of RETINA RETINAL DETACHMENT RETINAL ISCHEMIA OPTIC NERVE DISEASE OPTIC NEURITIS INFLAMMATION from MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS SEVERE GLAUCOMA TRAUMA

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Atropine is contraindicated in which of the following conditions :-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute Congestive Glaucoma Atropine is contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma. Acute congestive or angle closure glaucoma is caused by the opposition of the peripheral iris against the trabecular meshwork. This obstructs the aqueous outflow by closing an already narrow-angle of the anterior chamber leading to an acute increase in intraocular pressure Management of acute congestive glaucoma includes:- rapid lowering of IOP by mannitol or glycerol, acetazolamide, and topical antiglaucoma drugs. Definitive management is done by laser peripheral iridotomy or filtration surgery. Atropine is indicated as cycloplegic to reduce pain and prevent synechiae in corneal ulcers and acute anterior uveitis.

Highyeild:

ACUTE CONGESTIVE ANGLE CLOSURE GLAUCOMA Due to rapid ↑ in 10P Defined as: At least 2 of the following SYMPTOMS Ocular pain Nausea/ vomiting Hx of intermittent BOV with halos o Plus 3 of the following SIGNS IOP > 21mmHg Conjunctival injection Corneal epithelial edema Mid-dilated non reactive pupil Shallower chamber in presence of occlusion

Extraedge:

Closed-angle glaucomas are characterized by a shallow anterior chamber that forces the root of the mid-dilated iris forward against the trabecular network, obstructing the drainage of aqueous humor and increasing the intraocular pressure. SIGNS Reduced visual acuity Cornea cloudy and oedematous Pupil oval, fixed and moderately dilated Ciliary injection 5 . Eye feels hard on palpation Elevated IOP (50-100 mmHg) Narrow chamber Angle with peripheral Aqueous flare and cells Gonioscopy- complete peripheral iridocorneal contact. Ophthalmoscopy - optic disc oedema and hyperaemia

Table:

#MANTRA Acute Closed Angle Glaucoma: Pathogenesis and clinical findings
